The 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnation method, and the effects of Mn, Mo doping on the structure and NH3-SCR performance of Fe-based catalysts were investigated. The 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst showed highest NH3-SCR activity (over 80 % NO conversion at 200–400 °C) and best long-time stability. Especially, the conversion rate of NO was 97 % at 250–300 °C. The introduction of Mn, Mo increased the surface acidity and redox ability of the 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst and improved the dispersion of active components (Fe). DFT calculations showed that the Mo-MnFe2O4 (311) surface over 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst had the strongest adsorption capacity for NO and NH3, which was more favorable for the SCR process, and this result was consistent with the NH3-SCR activity test. Kinetics results indicated the apparent activation energy of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst decreased by 39 % when compared to 5 %Fe/TiO2. It was evident that the addition of Mn and Mo reduced the apparent activation energy of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR Fe-Mn-Mo/TiO2 Catalyst low-temperature activity Transient kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Industrial furnaces, petrochemicals, coal-fired power plants, metallurgy, etc. all produce large amounts of nitrogen oxides (NOx). NOx emissions could have a severe ecological impact [1,2]. Selective catalytic reduction with NH3(NH3-SCR) was currently the most effective and mature technology for treating NOx. Currently, the widely commercialized V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts were limited in further development and application due to their toxicity, and there was an urgent need for an environmentally friendly SCR catalyst with excellent NO reduction activity. As a result, more and more researchers were turning to iron oxides, which were inexpensive and have excellent redox properties. However, single-component iron oxide catalysts had poor activity and narrow operating temperature window, especially the low-temperature catalytic activity was not desirable. Therefore, improving the thermal stability, surface acidity and redox ability of Fe-TiO2 catalysts through modification or doping to enhance the medium and low temperature of catalysts was a current research hotspot. Mn and Mo could improve the redox ability and surface acidity of catalysts in SCR reactions [3–6]. Chen et al. [7] investigated the effect of Mn-doped polyhedral CeO2 catalysts on SCR performance. The was shown that Mn improved the redox ability of the catalyst. Xie et al. [8] studied Mn-doped FeVO4 catalysts and used them for NH3-SCR reaction. The introduction of Mn improved the selectivity of N2, and inhibited the production of N2O. On the other hand, Wang et al. [9] developed a Mo-doped CuO catalyst and showed that Mo doping increased Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. Tang et al. [10] found that Mo doping of Ce0.3FeOx catalyst improved the surface acidity of the catalyst and increased the denitrification activity. It was shown that Mo could promote the dispersion of MnOx on the carrier surface and broadened the operating temperature window of the catalyst. Although there have been many reports on Mn and Mo doping, there were few reports on Mn and Mo co-doped Fe-TiO2 catalysts for NH3-SCR field. DFT calculations can simulate gas adsorption processes and show useful details of molecular reactions. It was well known that NH3 and NO adsorption played a key role in the NH3-SCR reaction [11,12], therefore, the study of NH3 and NO adsorption could provide theoretical support for catalyst design. In addition, clarifying the kinetic properties of catalyst NH3-SCR denitration reaction can provide data support for the simulation design of NH3-SCR denitration reactor. Combining kinetic and DFT studies can make the catalyst more practical for application. In this study, a transition metal (M=Mn, Mo)-doped Fe-M/TiO2 catalyst was designed for NH3-SCR showing high activity (≥96 %) and stability (≥20 h) at low temperatures (250–300 °C). Meanwhile, the effects of Mn and Mo doping on the activity, structure, redox ability, surface acidity and dispersibility of the catalysts were also investigated. Based on XRD results, the effects of surface properties of Fe2O3 on the (104) plane and MnFe2O4 on the (111) plane, MnFe2O4 on the (311) plane, and Mo-MnFe2O4 on the (311) plane on NH3-SCR performance were elucidated by DFT calculations. The kinetic test results showed that the doping of Mn and Mo could reduce the apparent activation energy of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalytic preparation All catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. The calculation of active components and auxiliary loading was determined by the mass ratio of metal oxide to carrier TiO2. Take 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 as an example: take appropriate amounts of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Chengdu Kelong Chemicals Co., Ltd), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (Sinopharm Group) and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (Chengdu Kelong Chemicals Co., Ltd), add deionized water to dissolve, add a certain amount of TiO2 (Wuhan Crystal Solar Technology Co., Ltd) to the solution, impregnate for 45 min and then dry using the 80 °C water bath, place the dried sample in an oven at 110 °C overnight to dry. Finally, it was sintered at 500 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace, the obtained powder was named 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2. 2.2 Catalytic performance test Catalysts were tested for NH3-SCR performance in the fixed-bed quartz reactor. Total reaction gas composition were O2 (3 %), NO (400 ppm) and NH3 (400 ppm), with Ar as the equilibrium gas. The flow rate of reaction gas was controlled by a mass flow meter and the total flow rate of the reaction gas was 100 ml/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of only 30,000 h−1. 0.2 g of catalyst (pellet, 20–40 meshes) was used for activity testing, and the reactor quartz tube was 6 mm inner diameter and 33 cm long. Concentration of NO in the reacted exhaust gas using VARO Plus flue gas analyzer from MRU at 150–450 °C. The NO conversion rate result was obtained by the Eq. (1) . (1) N O conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % 2.3 Catalysts characterization The crystallinity and physical phases of the catalysts were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, X'pertpro MPD, Shimadzu, Japan) in the 2θ measurement range of 10° to 80°. Cu-Kα was the X-ray diffraction source. Low-temperature liquid nitrogen adsorption and desorption instrument (JW-BK132, JWGB SCI. &TECH, China) was used to determine the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) of catalysts The SEM images of all samples were acquired by field emission scanning electron microscope (JEOL 7800F, Japan). TEM tests were performed on a Nissan JEOL transmission electron microscope to test the microscopic morphology of the catalyst samples at the nanoscale. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were recorded on Thermo ESCAlab250 instrument. The excitation source (hν =1486.46 eV) was an Al Kα-ray monochromatic microfocused monochromatic source. The binding energies (BE) of various elements were calibrated using a C 1s peak (284.8 eV). Hydrogen programmed temperature rise reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were done on an automated chemisorption analyzer (FINESORB-3010). 100 mg of catalyst was used for the test, treated in an atmosphere of Ar at 300 oC for 1 h. After cooling to approximately 45 °C, the atmosphere was changed to a mixture of H2-Ar (10 % H2 by volume) and then steadily increased to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C/min. TCD signal intensity detection of H2 consumption NH3 programmed temperature desorption analysis was performed using a BSD-C200 Automatic Chemisorption Analyzer (BEISHIDE, Beijing, China) to measure the surface acidity and ammonia adsorption capacity of the catalyst. The SCR catalyst (60 mg) was incubated at 300 °C for 60 min in a helium (He) atmosphere, cooled to 40 °C, and then maintained for 60 min with a 5 % NH3/He mixture. Finally, NH3-TPD was tested by heating the catalyst to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C /min under helium (He) atmosphere. 2.4 Computational details The spin-polarized density generalized theory was calculated by the CASTEP module in the Materials Studio 2019 software. During the calculations, PW91 under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used, and the Brillouin zone was sampled by a 1 × 1 × 1 Gamma grid, the plane wave truncation energy was set to 500 eV, and the convergence criterion of the atomic forces was set to 0.05 eV/Å. All the atomic and lattice parameters in the model were fully relaxed. The structure optimized model and model parameters were shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1 for the geometrically optimized configuration and lattice parameters of Fe2O3 and MnFe2O4, respectively. The bottom two layers of atoms were fixed, and the surface layers of atoms and adsorbed molecules were chirped. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was established to ensure that the adjacent plate layers in the z-axis direction did not interact with the adsorbed molecules. Formula for calculating the adsorption energy of gas molecules: (2) E ads = E ( adsorbate + surface ) − E ( adsorbate ) − E ( surface ) 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts The effects of metal additives Mn and Mo doping on the activity of 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalysts were investigated. Fig. S1 showed the effect of different Mn contents on the catalytic activity. As could be seen from the figure, the moderate addition of Mn could significantly enhance the activity of the catalyst at low temperatures and expand the temperature window of the operating activity. The catalyst denitrification activity reached 93 % at 250 °C when the Mn content was 3 %, excessive Mn participation in ammonia oxidation reaction was detrimental to the SCR reaction. Moderate amounts of Mo could increase the number of acid sites on the catalyst surface. Fig. S2 showed the effect of different Mo contents on the activity of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-xMo/TiO2 catalyst, too much Mo was detrimental to SCR activity. When the Mo content was 3 %, the denitrification activity reached 99 % at 250 °C, and the operating temperature window based on 80 % denitrification activity was T80=200–400 °C, which exhibited the optimal denitrification activity. As displayed in Fig. 2 , the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst showed the best denitrification performance and the lowest N2O production (Fig. S3). After doping Mn and Mo, the NO conversion rate increased by 20 %, and NO conversion rate of 97 % was achieved at 250–300 °C. More importantly, the corresponding results in Fig. 4 showed that the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst retained its original activity after 20 h. In order to explicitly elaborate the differences in the activity of catalysts prepared by different metal additive doping, the kinetic studies of NH3-SCR with catalysts were performed in the dynamic region with NO conversion below 20 % and the calculated results were presented in Fig. 3 . The obtained apparent activation energy for the catalysts were as follows: 5 %Fe/TiO2 (40.08 kJ/mol)>5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 (32.02 kJ/mol)>5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 (29.25 kJ/mol). This showed that the apparent activation energy of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst decreased by 39 % when compared to that of 5 %Fe/TiO2. It was evident that the addition of Mn and Mo reduced the apparent activation energy of the 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst. Therefore, the doping of metals Mn and Mo reduced the catalyst activation energy and increases the SCR activity. This indicated that more active sites were generated, thus promoting the adsorption of NO molecules, as evidenced by the DFT results. 3.2 XRD results XRD tests can detect the dispersion and crystallinity of the catalyst. Fig. 5 showed the XRD patterns of 5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts. All catalysts showed the typical diffraction peaks of TiO2 [13], which showed that the structure of TiO2 carriers did not switch after Fe, Mn, and Mo loading. The diffraction peak of 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst at 2θ=33.15° belonged to Fe2O3, which was attributed to the (104) plane [JCPDS No. 33-0664]. The diffraction peak at 2θ=34.88°, 17.99° belonged to MnFe2O4, which were attributed to the (311) and (111) planes [JCPDS No. 38-0430]. MnFe2O4 had excellent low temperature denitrification activity as a denitrification catalyst [14,15]. The intensity of the catalyst peaks decreased with the addition of both active metals and additives, and the lowest peak intensity was observed for the co-doping of Mn and Mo, which demonstrated that the catalyst active components were highly dispersed, which was beneficial to the catalyst activity [16]. Table 2 showed the grain size of TiO2 (101). The grain size of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 % Mo/TiO2 catalyst was only 20.7 nm, which was 10 % less than that of the 5 % Fe/TiO2 catalyst. The addition of Mn and Mo additives significantly reduced the grain size of the 5 % Fe/TiO2 catalyst, thus raising the specific surface area of the catalyst. Therefore, the excellent low-temperature activity of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst due to the MnFe2O4 species on its surface as well as to the high dispersion of the active components and the small grain size. 3.3 BET results Fig. 6 showed the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the 5 % Fe/TiO2, 5 % Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %-Mn-3 %/Mo/TiO2 catalysts. All curves showed Langermuir type IV curves, which demonstrated that the catalysts had a complete TiO2 mesoporous structure. As shown in Table 2, the BET surface area of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 (52.53 m2 g−1) catalyst was larger than that of 5 % Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 (47.79 m2 g−1) and 5 %Fe/TiO2 (51.71 m2 g−1), which demonstrated that the simultaneous introduction of Mn and Mo enhanced the BET surface area of the catalyst. The bigger the specific surface area, the better the catalytic performance of the catalyst for NH3-SCR [17,18]. Combined with the activity test results, it shows that increasing the BET surface area was one of the critical aspects to promote the NH3-SCR performance. 3.4 SEM results Fig. 7 showed the SEM images of the 5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts. SEM images showed that three catalysts were composed of uniform and monodisperse spherical nanoparticles. The active components were distributed on the carrier in an amorphous state without agglomeration, indicating that the additive modification made the active components more dispersed. Therefore, the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent low-temperature denitrification activity. 3.5 TEM results Fig. 8 showed the TEM image of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst. It could be seen by Fig. 8(a) that the catalyst particles show good dispersion. The average particle size of TiO2 particles was only 20.7 nm, which was the same as the XRD calculation. After that, the crystal plane spacing in the catalyst 5 nm scale Fig. 8(b) was calculated by Digital Micrograph software, and the results were shown in Fig. 8(c) and (d), where the crystal plane with 0.353 nm spacing in Fig. 8(d) belonged to anatase TiO2 (101) [19], and the crystal plane with 0.259 nm spacing in Fig. 8(c) belonged to the (311) crystalline surface of MnFe2O4 [20]. 3.6 XPS results XPS characterization can determine the chemical state of the catalyst surface elements. Fig. 9 showed the XPS spectra of 5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 % Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 % Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts respectively, which were attributed to Ti4+ [21,22]. The Ti 2p peak positions did not change after the doping of Mn and Mo, which meant that the additive doping did not affect the carrier TiO2 chemical state. Fig. 9(b) showed the catalyst O 1s energy spectrum. The two types of oxygen in the catalyst had characteristic peaks at 529.8 eV (lattice oxygen Oβ) and 531.4 eV (surface adsorbed oxygen Oα) [23]. The doping of Mn and Mo shifted the electron binding energy of O 1s toward lower binding energy, indicating that the modification increased the electron cloud density of Oβ and Oα. This could be the result of some of the Mn or Mo entering the lattice of the catalyst and forming more oxygen vacancies [24]. As shown in Table 3 , the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts had higher Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio and usually, Oα was more active than Oβ, which accelerated the redox reaction in the SCR reaction due to the fast migration of Oα and lower binding energy [25]. Therefore, Mn and Mo auxiliary doping increased the Oα ratio was the main reason for the excellent low-temperature activity of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst. Fig. 9(c) showed the Fe 2p energy spectrum of the catalysts. The peaks of Fe3+appeared around 713.2 eV and 727.6 eV, and the peaks of Fe2+ appeared around 710.3 eV and 724.5 eV [26]. The ratios of Fe2+/(Fe3++ Fe2+) in the 5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts were calculated from the respective peak areas in the Fe 2p spectra (Table 3), which could be the result of electronic interactions of the Mn or Mo additives with the Fe to facilitate the formation of Fe2+. It was shown that the new species generated from the intermediate valence was the main cause of enhanced chemisorption of oxygen, thus enhancing the redox properties of the catalyst and facilitating the NH3-SCR denitrification reaction at low temperatures [3,27]. The Fe3+ and Fe2+ peaks of both 5 % Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts were shifted to the left when Mn or Mo was introduced, indicating that Mn or Mo caused a change in the chemical state of the active component Fe and that the additive was incorporated into the lattice of the catalyst [28]. Fig. 9(d) showed the XPS energy spectrum of Mn 2p. It could be found that there were mainly two valence states of Mn. The presence of two valence states of Mn2+ (around 641.4 eV, 652.5 eV) and Mn4+ (around 642.4 eV, 654.0 eV) could be found in the catalyst [29], which indicated the presence of MnO or MnFe2O4 compounds in the catalyst [30]. Also the electron binding energy of Mn4+ of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst was greater than that of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which implied that it was more accessible to electrons [31]. Comparing the analysis of the second auxiliary Mo-modified catalyst, the peaks of the catalyst carrier Ti 2p were not shifted significantly, while the electron binding energies of Fe 2p and Mn 2p were shifted, which demonstrated that the chemical states of Fe and Mn were changed in the Mo-modified catalysts and the chemical states of the TiO2 carrier were basically unchanged. 3.7 H2-TPR The reduction performance of the catalyst was very important for the NH3-SCR process [32]. Fig. 10 showed the H2-TPR profiles for different catalysts. The 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst had two reduction peaks: the peak around 300–400 °C was attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3→FeO [15,33] and the peak (β) located around 720–800 °C was attributed to the reduction of Ti4+→Ti3+ [34,35]. The Mn-doped 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst produced new reduction peaks (α) around 310–400 °C, which were belonged to the reduction of MnO2→Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 [36]. The Mn and Mo doped 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts produced new reduction peaks around 455 °C and 571 °C belonged to the reduction reaction of Mo6+→Mo4+→Mo at 400–600 °C for MoO3 [37]. There was an increase in the peak intensity of the Mn-doped 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst, compared with the 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst, while the reduction peak shifted toward the lower temperature. It indicated that more reducing species were generated, which made the reduction temperature lower, thus enhancing the low-temperature reduction of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The enhancement of catalyst redox was good for the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. Compared with that of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the reduction peak of the Mo-doped 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst was significantly enhanced. The increase in the intensity of the H2 depletion peak could be put down to the increase of surface defects and thus the increase in the surface oxygen species after the auxiliary Mo was embedded in the lattice structure of the catalyst. The reduction peaks(α, β) of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst shifted toward the high temperature direction, indicating that the strong interaction forces of the catalyst components were enhanced. The stronger the carrier-metal interaction, the greater the resistance to reduction and the higher the reduction temperature [38–41]. 3.8 NH3-TPD Surface acidity of different catalysts obtained by NH3-TPD test. Fig. 11 showed the NH3-TPD curves for 5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts. Both the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 and 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalysts had two desorption peaks. Peak 1 (<150 °C) was attributed to NH3 species adsorbed on weak acid sites [42], and peak 2 (300–500 °C) was attributed to NH3 species adsorbed on strong acid sites [43]. It was obvious that the introduction of Mn and Mo increased the surface acidity of the 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst. Compared with the other two catalysts (5 %Fe/TiO2, 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2), the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst showed sharper desorption peaks and the strong acid sites moved to higher temperatures, which implied that the introduction of Mo enhanced the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3 at high temperatures. In addition, the consumption of NH3 showed an increasing trend in ascending order of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 (0.1602 mmol/g) > 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 (0.1141 mmol/g) > 5 %Fe/TiO2 (0 mmol/g). The highest NH3 consumption of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst indicated that the introduction of metals Mn and Mo greatly increased the acidic sites of the catalyst. 3.9 DFT study Figs. 12 and 13 showed the adsorption models of NO and NH3 on the crystal surfaces of catalysts Fe2O3 (104), MnFe2O4 (111), MnFe2O4 (311) and MnFe2O4 (311). Table 3 showed the adsorption energies (Eads) of reactive molecules (NO, NH3) on the four crystal planes calculated according to Eq. (2). Notably, the Eads value of NH3 on the surface of MnFe2O4 (111) crystal was only −0.06 eV, which indicated that NH3 could only form physical adsorption on the surface of MnFe2O4 (111) and the rest was chemisorption. The Eads values of NO and NH3 on Fe2O3 (104) were −0.70 eV, −0.71 eV, −0.73 eV and −2.38 eV on the surface of MnFe2O4 (311), respectively. Apparently, the introduction of Mn significantly enhanced the adsorption capacity of the catalyst to the reaction molecules. In addition, the adsorption capacity of NO and NH3 on the surface of MnFe2O4 (311) was stronger than that on the surface of MnFe2O4 (111), indicating that the adsorption behavior of NO and NH3 on the surface of MnFe2O4 (311) was more favorable for the NH3-SCR reaction to occur. The adsorption energy of NO and NH3 on the Mo-MnFe2O4 (311) crystal surface was higher than that on the MnFe2O4 (311) crystal surface, and the doping of Mo enhanced the adsorption ability of NO and NH3 on the MnFe2O4 (311) surface, which proved that Mo enhanced the surface acidity of the catalyst and thus promoted the catalytic activity of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which corresponded to the activity test results. To understand the electronic structure of nitrogen adsorption on the catalyst surface at the molecular level, the partial densities of states (PDOS) of N and Fe in the clean and adsorption models were investigated. The results were shown in the Figs. 14–16 . After adsorption of NH3 and NO, all the peaks of N atoms were shifted to the deep energy level. This indicated that the adsorption of NO and NH3 on Fe2O3 (104), MnFe2O4 (311), and Mo-MnFe2O4 (311) were all strong interactions and significantly affect the electronic structure of Fe atoms after adsorption, as could be seen from the splitting peaks out of the Fermi energy level. In addition, compared with NH3 adsorption, NO adsorption was more stable because the orbital overlap of 2p of N and 3d of Fe in NO became more hybridized, and the electron interaction between the orbitals was more substantial. The comparison of the adsorbed PDOS maps on the surface of Fe2O3(104) and MnFe2O4(311) showed that the peaks of the Fe atom d orbit PDOS on the surface of MnFe2O4(311) split near the Fermi energy level, and the peaks intensity were enhanced, and the peak positions were shifted to the right. This indicated that the introduction of Mn atoms enhanced the redox ability of the catalyst and facilitates the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures. Comparing the two models of MnFe2O4 (311) surface and Mo-MnFe2O4 (311) surface, the energy level of d orbitals of surface Fe atoms became higher after surface Mo doping, which might be due to the generation of a large number of defects, and thus the adsorption capacity of the reacting gas became stronger, which was consistent with its lowest adsorption energy (Eads) (Table 4 ). 3.10 Reaction mechanism The possible reaction mechanism of 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst for NH3-SCR was obtained based on XPS, NH3-TPD and other characterization as shown in Fig. 17 (a). DFT studies showed that Mo-MnFe2O4 crystals were involved in the NH3-SCR reaction process, NH3 adsorbed on Fe3+, N in NH3 and Fe had electron transfer, Fe3+ became Fe2+, but Fe2+ was not favorable for the NH3-SCR reaction. The introduction of Mn improved the catalyst's redox properties, produced more reduced species, and the electron transfer was easier. The introduction of Mn improved the redox performance of the catalyst, produced more reduced species, and made electron transfer easier. As a result, a redox cycle of Mn and Fe (Mn4++Fe2+↔Fe3++Mn2+) occurs in the NH3-SCR reaction, and the redox cycle facilitated the adsorption and activation of NH3 to form NH2. NH2 was an intermediate product generated by the activation and oxidation of NH3 in the SCR reaction [2,44]. NH3 adsorbed at Lewis acid sites was dehydrogenated by activation to form NH2, which reacted with gaseous NO to form NH2NO, which decomposed to form N2 and H2O [45,46]. In addition, Mn species could easily form bidentate and bridging nitrate with NO, promoting the oxidation of NO to NO2 [42,47], which was favorable to the "fast SCR" reaction [48]. Meanwhile, Fe could promote the adsorption reaction between nitrate and NH3, thus improving the SCR activity [49]. The introduction of Mo could increase the number of surface acid sites, including Brønsted and Lewis sites [50], which was favorable for the adsorption of NHx [51]. In addition, the doping of Mn and Mo produced more and more active adsorption sites, which was consistent with the kinetic results. In addition, the doping of Mo enhanced the adsorption energy of Mo-MnFe2O4 on NH3 and NO. It made the interaction force of each component enhanced and the Mo-MnFe2O4 crystalline structure more stable, thus, the catalyst was characterized by high stability. Based on the above discussion, considering the structure, morphology and redox properties of the catalyst 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2, a possible denitrification mechanism was again proposed. As shown in Fig. 17(b), NH3 is first adsorbed on Fe atoms, and then an N-H bond is broken to generate NH2, which reacts with gas-phase NO to generate the intermediate product NH2NO, and finally NH2NO decomposes to generate N2 and H2O, following the E-R mechanism. The whole reaction process could be written as: (3) O2(gas) → 2O(ads) (4) NH3(gas) →NH3(ads)over-Fe (5) NH3(gas) + O(ads) → NH2(ads) + OH(ads) (6) NO(gas) + NH2(ads) → NH2NO(ads) (7) NH2NO(ads) → N2(gas) + H2O 4 Conclusion The 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst prepared by impregnation method showed excellent catalytic performance and long-term stability in NH3-SCR. The NO conversion was nearly 100 % at 350 °C, while the operating temperature window based on 80 % denitrification activity was T80 = 200–400 °C. Furthermore, the doping of Mn and Mo could reduce the apparent activation energy. SEM and TEM results showed that the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst had high dispersion. XPS showed that the introduction of Mn and Mo additives enhanced the increased Oα ratio of the catalysts. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD showed that Mn, Mo enhanced the redox capacity and surface acidity of the catalysts. Meanwhile, we proved by the DFT theory study that the introduction of Mn and Mo could make the catalyst better adsorb NO and NH3, which was verified in the activity test experiment. coredata.dc:description: The 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnation method, and the effects of Mn, Mo doping on the structure and NH3-SCR performance of Fe-based catalysts were investigated. The 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst showed highest NH3-SCR activity (over 80 % NO conversion at 200–400 °C) and best long-time stability. Especially, the conversion rate of NO was 97 % at 250–300 °C. The introduction of Mn, Mo increased the surface acidity and redox ability of the 5 %Fe/TiO2 catalyst and improved the dispersion of active components (Fe). DFT calculations showed that the Mo-MnFe2O4 (311) surface over 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst had the strongest adsorption capacity for NO and NH3, which was more favorable for the SCR process, and this result was consistent with the NH3-SCR activity test. Kinetics results indicated the apparent activation energy of the 5 %Fe-3 %Mn-3 %Mo/TiO2 catalyst decreased by 39 % when compared to 5 %Fe/TiO2. It was evident that the addition of Mn and Mo reduced the apparent activation energy of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of the Fe-Mn-Mo/TiO2 catalyst and its DFT calculations and kinetics
